news_items.content: Here is the rewritten news article:
India's government has announced plans to upgrade laboratories at 2,676 government schools in Tamil Nadu to become hi-tech facilities, at a cost of Rs65 crore.

In other news, a traffic diversion plan near the RBI subway station in Chennai aims to improve traffic flow. Meanwhile, Chennai Metrowater has stepped up its sewer maintenance efforts by using robots and additional vehicles this monsoon season.

Another development involves three college students who drowned in the Coimbatore River. Police have arrested two individuals for their involvement in a cocaine seizure in Chennai, while 8 people were held for altering traffic lights on a bridge.

Additionally, two Kollywood actors have been arrested in connection with allegations of drug use in Chennai. In other news, India's government has announced plans to implement facial recognition technology in CCTV cameras at airports.

A recent report from the Gandhi Market eviction drive in Ennore highlighted concerns about community opposition and social unrest. The Vice President has expressed support for a review of this matter.

The Supreme Court has dismissed a case involving the demolition of buildings by India, with Pak's reconstruction efforts being called out for allegedly supporting terrorism. A new initiative aims to provide aid for postpartum recovery in Chennai, while Dawoodi Bohra's Ashara Mubarak celebrations are underway.

In sports news, Prime Minister Narendra Modi shared an image of himself eating 'gajar ka halwa' in zero gravity on social media. The 28th-day pilgrimage to the holy site is expected to attract millions of devotees this year.

The latest artificial intelligence-related news focuses on companies pushing for more AI capabilities, with Nvidia's title as the most valuable company on AI momentum being recently reclaimed. A report highlighted ongoing debates between Microsoft and OpenAI over a contractual provision related to artificial general intelligence.

In other developments, the Indian government has expressed concerns about author usage of AI in scholarly works, while Meta reportedly hires additional researchers from OpenAI to develop its own AI technology.
